chunks.text: Welcome to database design and SQL. Databases are crucial for storing and managing data in applications.
Relational databases organize data in tables with rows and columns. Each table represents an entity with attributes.
Primary keys uniquely identify each row in a table. Foreign keys establish relationships between tables.
Normalization reduces data redundancy and improves data integrity. It involves organizing data into multiple related tables.
First normal form eliminates repeating groups. Second normal form removes partial dependencies. Third normal form removes transitive dependencies.
SQL, Structured Query Language, is used to interact with relational databases. Main commands are SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE.
SELECT statements retrieve data from tables. You can filter with WHERE, sort with ORDER BY, and limit results.
JOINs combine data from multiple tables. INNER JOIN, LEFT JOIN, RIGHT JOIN, and FULL JOIN serve different purposes.
Aggregate functions like COUNT, SUM, AVG, MAX, and MIN perform calculations on sets of rows. GROUP BY groups results.
Indexes improve query performance by creating data structures for faster lookups. They trade storage space for speed.
Transactions ensure data consistency with ACID properties: Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability.
Stored procedures and triggers add business logic to the database layer. Views provide simplified data access.
NoSQL databases offer alternatives for specific use cases. Document, key-value, graph, and column-family stores have different strengths.
Good database design is critical for application performance and maintainability. Practice with real-world scenarios to improve skills.
